How beautiful, Salerno!  is thy bay;</br>How green thy heights monastic! — let me stand</br>On yonder mountain, ('tis the break of day,)</br>And view, outstretch'd below, a sacred land</br>Beneath the day-blush indistinctly grand.</br>Here beauty smiled, and valour boldly fought;—</br>Who would not fight when beauty gives command?</br>Here, with unclouded mind, the scholar sought</br>Those academes, where learning every science taught.

Hail, thou thrice-blessed sun!  how very few</br>With thankfulness enjoy thy genial beams;</br>Or from the mountain's height are wont to view,</br>With feelings of delight, morn's earliest gleams,—</br>The mist uprising o'er the distant streams!</br>The morn's an emblem of our second birth;</br>When we shall quit this pleasant land of dreams,</br>The sun, to those who feel and know their worth,</br>Predicts eternal glories for the sons of earth.

Here let me pause.  The blood of Christ was spilt,</br>To free mankind from death's eternal chains:—</br>Not through indulgences to cancel guilt,</br>Or from the tainted heart wash out its stains,</br>Unless repentance chasten it with pains.</br>The spiritual pride of Rome must yield</br>To pure philosophy, that now disdains</br>Those Papal fiats to which kings appeal'd,</br>When mad ambition used religion as its shield.

Ye haughty Cardinals, who o'er the minds</br>Of despot sovereigns held despotic sway,—</br>No heir to your self-willed ambition binds</br>Nobility, with iron links, to-day;—</br>Your power anomalous has past away!</br>Ye were most potent ministers, and well,</br>With eagle swiftness, pounced upon your prey.</br>Yet are ye greater now than those who dwell</br>On Nicolo's vast heights, or hermit in his cell.

Ye have upraised indeed the monarch's power,—</br>That it might fall from high with greater force:</br>The chains ye forged were broken in an hour,</br>By outraged multitudes, without remorse.</br>Affection is true loyalty's prime source,—</br>Upmounts ambition, like a seeled dove;</br>While vulgar spirits wonder at its course,—</br>Higher and higher yet, it mounts above</br>Royalty's self, that scorns (how blind!)  the people's love.

A few years pass away, and then — farewell</br>To wealth and rank, and all we hold most dear!—</br>For ever and for ever we must dwell</br>With saints or daemons, — death approacheth near.</br>Why quakes yon mighty potentate with fear?</br>He leaves a name behind; and heroes toil</br>To gain — what many have who ne'er appear</br>But in the poet's fabled lays, — they spoil</br>Others' repose, and lose their own through vain turmoil!

Are not the heroes of romance as known</br>As Caesar, Attila, or Ammon's son?</br>What an unreal thing is that renown</br>Which after ages give — for battles won—</br>To him, who from this bustling world is gone!</br>He wanders through the mansions of the dead,—</br>Where joy ne'er smiled, the light has never shone,—</br>Vexed by the groans of those who daily bled,</br>That through — else happy — lands their lord might ruin spread!</br>
